text: So I'll get started.

Title of my talk,
Control-oriented Learning

for Dynamical Systems and
what this will revolve around

is my work at the interplay
between learning and control,
particularly, for robotics.

So what this is motivated
by is that if we

look at each of these
robotic systems on their own

at least from a
dynamics perspective,

we're pretty good at
coming up with some sort

of first principles model
of each of these systems.

Where the complexity arises
is where these robots

are operating in
different domains

and under certain conditions
like icy roads, and contact,

and under different
wind conditions.

And these are the
things that are

difficult to model
analytically and these

are the reasons why we turn
to data-driven learning.

When we can't write
down the model by hand,

so we look to data
and try and figure out

a model for the system overall
or at least some addendum
as a model we already have.

But a lot of the
fundamental and naive ways

you might think about doing
learning from machine learning

don't always work
very well in practice

when you're talking about
closed-loop control.

So for example, naive
regression where you just

minimize 2-norm
loss, may work well

in minimizing one
step open-loop error

but control tasks
happen over long time
horizons in closed-loop.

So regression--
what you might find

is that regression for the
system and then deploying

a learned model for the system
that was learned with naive

regression, would
diverge over time

with compounding errors
over multiple time steps
during closed-loop control.

So what we need to do, at least
what I argue in this talk,

is that we need to orient the
learning problem around what

we're ultimately interested in
which is closed-loop control

or the downstream-control
objective--

this is the terminology
that we use--

so rather than just the
model fitting objective.

So the idea which we call
control-oriented learning

is that we should
condition the model

to perform better and be
more adaptable in closed

loop in comparison to models
that are learned naively
to minimize open-loop error.

So today, I'll discuss three
different lines of work

that we've developed time
permitting to orient learning
around closed-loop control.

The first one
involved translating

the concept of stabilizability
or controllability

into algebraic
conditions that we're

going to use as a regularizer
for closed-loop control

performance during
offline learning.

The second take is a
little bit different.

It involves structuring
our model appropriately

offline in a manner that's
generally applicable

but it naturally yields a
useful closed-loop controller
based on LQR.

And then the final
work I'll talk about

is shifting more towards the
online setting and specifically,

using meta-learning to
learn a good extension

to a nominal model
that you specify maybe

through first
principles and learning,

an extension to it
that we can adapt well
online for adaptive control.

So I'll get started with
the first project which

was joint work with some
folks at Google and MIT

and it's going back to
this regression problem.

And what we want to do
is integrate some notion

of stabilizability
or the ability

to stabilize the
system as a constraint,

with the key idea being
that what this should do

is prune the hypothesis
space of functions

that we're fitting
over, that we're

searching over, and finding
one that somehow attuned
to closed-loop control.

So the key question--
so in stabilizability,

what I mean by that
is there exists

a controller that as a function
of my current state where I am,

where I want to be
x star, and ensures

that x of t, my current state,
goes towards my x star of t
over time.

That's what I mean
by stabilizability
in the general sense.

The key thing we
need to overcome here

is, if we want to
try this out is

we have to be able to
describe stabilizability

algebraically to construct
an optimization problem

that we can solve
to fit a model.

So to do this, we
turn to something
called contraction theory.

So if we look at--
let's consider

control-affine
dynamics, x dot equals
f of x plus b of x times u.

And what contraction
theory starts off by doing

is linearizing the dynamics
but maintaining the dependence
on your linearization point.

So you look everywhere,
state, and input-wise,

and you look at the
local linear dynamics

or the variational dynamics
to be more specific.

This is a family
of linear systems

and it's an exact description
of small variations

of your dynamics near
your linearization point.

And this is a linear
system at least

in your variations,
delta x and delta u.

So you can do is,
we can construct

this notion of local
energy or local distance.

And this is a square
distance but it's weighted
by a metric called m of x.

It's a positive definite
matrix function.

It basically generalizes
the notion of distance

and it allows it to depend
on your linearization point.

So like I said, we're
generalizing the notion

of squared distance
with some quantity

that allows it to depend on
where you're linearizing it.

And this thing that we're
weighting the distance with

is what's known as a control
contraction metric or CCM.

And the idea is that we have
a quadratic notion of energy.
We have a linear system.

So anybody who's done
any control theory, that

should scream out to you, do
some linear control design.

That's our bread and butter
as control theorists,

is linear control design
with quadratic costs

or quadratic energy functions
or Lyapunov functions.

So the idea is that if we can
design a linear controller,

a local linear controller or a
variational controller that's

linear in the variation in
x and design in such a way

that this differential energy is
decreasing locally everywhere.

Well, if it's decreasing
locally everywhere

and I integrate that
differential control delta

u between two
points, x and x star,

so long shortest paths
between x and x star,

I back out another
control and through some--

a lot more math than I intend to
get into in this presentation,

we can show that
by integrating out

control for the original system,
we can get something that's

stabilizing for
the original system

and it basically makes x
of t go towards x of t.

So the metric m of x together
with this energy decrease

condition, which I haven't
really put any specifics on yet,

together forms a certificate for
stabilizability of our system.

So we have dynamics
and we've introduced

this additional function along
with some conditions that

need to be satisfied to
make the system stabilize.

So without going
into any detail,

really, about how this is
derived, the idea that-- there's

few things I want
to point out, is

that it depends on
the dynamics which

go into, now, our model
fitting objective at the top.

And we also have this
decrease condition

that ends up looking like
a matrix inequality that

depends on both the dynamics
and well, the inverse metric.

So you've added an extra thing
that you're trying to learn

and it acts as a certificate
for the stabilizability

of the dynamics functions
that you're fitting to data.

The key problem still of
those two problems, one

is that the constraints
are infinite dimensional.

Much like a Lyapunov
type analysis,
you want it to hold for all x.

But we can't tractably enforce
this as a constraint other
than in some certain conditions.

So what we do is, we relax this
and say sample some x points

and turn this into a finite
number of constraints.

And there's no data associated
with these constraints.

There's no output or
labels for this data.

I can sample as many x's in
the state space as I want.

So I can cover the state space
as densely or as sparsely
as I want.

The only labels that show up
are in the actual model fitting
objective.

So the other problem here
is that it's non-convex.

You have matrix inequalities
that multiples of f and w
but it's bi-convex.

So what we do to solve is, we
linearly parameterize our metric

and dynamics and do alternating
convex solves until we converge
to some local optimum.

And so we actually
did this on hardware
with real data with a quadrotor.

And on the left, we've
done naive model fitting

and on the right, we've
done our approach.

And what we find is
that the one on the left
is not going to do so well.

It's going to start
oscillating a bit right here

and then it starts to go out
of control and then crashing.

While this one on
the right, manages

to track the figure eight that
we've commanded it to track.

And keep in mind, this is a
quadrant model that's sort

of learned from
scratch, so it's--

we're not providing
any base model for it.

We wanted to just see
how well does this method

work for learning a
model from scratch.

So with that, I'll move into
the second project which takes
a different spin on things.

And it will still be an
offline model learning

and this was with
some folks at MIT.

But it takes the
approach instead

of trying to come up with an
addendum like an extra function,

an extra certificate function,
it looks at how do we do control

or how do we build controllers
for actual physical systems.

Well often, they have
some structure to them

that yields a
controller in some way.

So for a mechanical
system, for example,

it has this nice Lagrangian
form that, for example, you

could do feedback
linearizing control on it
and it depends on the--

second order form is specific
to yielding that controller.

Something that's a little more
fundamental, the linear systems.

We have linear
systems, we have a lot

of like I said, bread and
butter for control theorists.

Linear systems--
there's a lot of theory

in designing stabilizing
controllers for them.

Specifically, we can
specify a quadratic cost

and do LQR control which is
optimal for linear systems.

So it's this idea of
structure-informing control

design that we're sort
of latching onto here.

It turns out that this
linear-like structure can also

be identified for
nonlinear systems.

So if we have f of x plus
b of x times u again,

let's say we can
always factor this--

it's fundamental
theorem of calculus--

we can always factor this as
f at zero plus a of x times x.

So it's some constant
offset plus all the terms

in your Taylor expansion
that you can always
factor out an x from.

And for such systems, OK, well,
this looks like a linear system
so we can do--

we can solve a Riccati equation
at each feedback timestamp

for each x we encounter and
do LQR-like control for it.

And it turns out in practice,
this work pretty well

and can do even better than LQR
control for nonlinear systems.

So a similar factorization
exists for aerodynamics
for any control-affine system.

So the idea of being if you
write the dynamics of x tilde
dot-- x tilde is x minus x star.

So where you are minus
where you want to go,

it turns out you can
factor in a similar way

where you have some matrix
function times x tilde plus b
of x times u tilde.

And you can solve a state what's
called a state dependent Riccati

equation and do feedback in
a non-linear manner using

linear-like tools and it
works pretty well in practice.

I think there's some
analogy with what

we talked about before with
the certificate-based feedback
with contraction theory.

So CCM based or
contraction theory-based

feedback you-- as long
as you have a decrease

condition satisfied,
you're guaranteed
to be exponentially stable.

It's a guarantee where this
bottom line here is just

a decrease condition I've
written out for the closed-loop

system with some controller
pi and without getting--

you don't have to know
every term in here

but the critical
thing is to notice

that it depends on
state and input samples,

it depends on your dynamics,
a controller, and a metric.

So these three different
things you're learning.

Dynamics, controller, and
some certificate function.

That's a lot of things
to try and fit to data.

In contrast, this Riccati
equation-based feedback,

it's a heuristic,
it's locally optimal,

it's no guarantees
on stabilizability

but it does work
well in practice.

And what you're
doing is, you're only

depending on some
factors form the dynamics

and then you're doing Riccati
equation-based control.

You're not learning a
separate certificate function.

You're not learning a
separate controller.

The structure of the dynamics
yields your controller design.

So what prior work has done is
they've-- what they've tried

to do is, let's try and let's
take this regression loss,

let's take this certificate
decrease condition,

turn it into an
auxiliary loss term,

and try and fit all these
functions to data at the same
time.

What we propose is try to
extract this structure out
of the dynamics.

Just learn the dynamics
and the structure

that enables Riccati
equation-based control

with an auxiliary loss
that sort of ensures

that these factorizations
are valid or consistent.

And so what we're
learning here is

the dynamics and
factorizations of the dynamics.

So instead, focus on learning
the dynamics and some details

about them and do Riccati
equation-based control.

So in a sense that
you're learning less,

but the hope is that it still
yields an effective controller.

So this is precisely
what we did.

So in simulation, we did
this planar quad example

where we wanted to track
this double loop trajectory.

And going from left to
right, what we've done

is it's an increase
in the data set size.

So we're going to
start-- we're going

to look at how much
data do we need

for each different type
of method to do well.

And on the bottom, I'm going to
plot the closed-loop trajectory.

So this is a baseline
linearization-based LQR.

So linearize around your current
point, solver quad equation,
and apply that control.

So this is the oracle so to
speak with the known dynamics.
So that's pretty well.

Then we did-- so this
method is, basically
fit your dynamics to data.

Just do naive regression and
do linearization-based LQR
on that model.

And we find it takes a while
before it starts to do well.

We then tried out
the CCM based--

basically the idea of
learning dynamics controller
and certificate.

And again, also
struggles a bit to get up

to the same level
of performance.
We do our method.

It does really well even
for a low amount of data.

This is purely learning the
dynamics and at the same time,

learning some structure
and the dynamics

to enable non-linear
LQR-like control.
And we found it's very--

enables very
data-efficient learning.

And in this plot, we did it
for two different systems.

And along the x-axis is,
again, the data set size

and on the upper vertical axis
is sort of RMS trajectory error.

And we've taken sort of
multiple random seeds

and figured out the
distribution in these results.

And we get similar case where as
you increase the amount of data,
you could do better.

But our method in green
already does really
well for low amounts of data.

And in fact, for enough data,
it beats out the oracle.

And the key thing
here is to remember

that we're learning
a controller that's

inherently non-linear
while the oracle is

using a linearization-based
controller.

So remember I said that
non-linear based control

we hope it does better than
linearization-based control
and it does in a lot of cases.
So we can find--

even now when we're
learning the dynamics,
we still get that happening.

So overall, what we've
seen is that enforcing

this factorized structure
enables a type of control

and outperforms and is
more sample-efficient

than naive and
certificate-based methods.

I've got a couple of
minutes and I'll sort of--

I might have to go a little
fast for this next section.
Forgive me.

But we'll move into
the final section

which will be more about the
adaptive and online setting.

So last two were about
learning a model offline
and deploying it online.

But like I said
often, we're pretty

good at driving at least
some basic model by hand

and then maybe what we want
to do is fine-tune it online.

So here, we have a typical
feedback loop from state

to controller to system and then
you have your feedback arrow

going backwards,
taking the state back
to the input to the controller.

For an arm, it
could be desired--

your state is your position
and velocity of your joints.

And usually in a
controller like I said,

we're relying on some knowledge
of the system and the system

model that we're using
consists of maybe two things,
both structure and parameters.

Structure could be
the fact that force
equals mass times acceleration.

Parameters are maybe the mass
and shape of your payload.

That maybe those are
uncertain especially

if you're doing pick
and place operations.

Your mass of your end effector
and the inertia that you're
dealing with are changing.

So what adaptive
control does is it says,

OK, well, maybe we don't know
the value of these parameters

but we maintain estimates and
try and change them on online
and learn them online.

And what's interesting is
that a defining characteristic

of adaptive control is that
it can guarantee tracking

convergence, but
parameter convergence

is only guaranteed as
a secondary result.

So the parameters don't
have to converge but you'll
get tracking convergence.
Little odd but the theory works.

So the idea is that,
this is sort of naturally

a form of control-oriented
learning or adapting

parameters on a need-to-know
basis for control.

So the tricky part is maybe
we don't know the structure.

So maybe for an
arm, we can write it

but for a drone in
wind conditions,

it's hard maybe to derive the
interaction with the drone
and aerodynamic forces.

So the idea is that--
what we propose to do

is learn this model
for these forces

and the adaptive part is
maybe just the last layer

of this deep model
that we want to learn.

And I think I'm
running out of time

but the idea is that, if
we have data from a drone

from multiple different
days when we're flying it

or multiple different
conditions that we fly it in,

we can treat each one
as a task if we use
the meta-learning vernacular.

And the idea is that the
dynamics, the forcing dynamics

that we don't know are
different for each condition.

So the idea of meta-learning
is learn some shared structure,

some shared features for each
of these different conditions

and adapt some
parameters online that
are specific to either task.

So this is the concept
with meta-learning

and what prior work has done
is done this with a regression

objective, basically
differentiating

through least squares
or a data fit objective,

and we do it instead
with a control objective.

So we actually
simulate the system

and then back propagate
through closed-loop simulation

instead of just back propagating
through least squares objective.
And I'll skip through.
But it turns out--

so our method or
sorry, the baselines

are in orange and green,
and our method is in blue.

So you can see a drastic
difference in performance there.

I apologize for
rushing at the end

but I'll turn it over to
questions, I guess, now.

So if you have any questions
including on the last part,
go for it.
Yes.

On the previous,

In general.

I'm just seeing always

The method is pretty

So the delta between our

Increases when with

Yes.

Yes.

So the first one
is control-affine.
F of x plus b of x times u.

With contraction theory,
there are some assumptions

about the system
that make it simpler

to apply these inequality
conditions to construct them.

One of which is some sparsity in

for mechanical systems.

We hope that we can divide our

and it comes up with

There's one assumption

So I guess you have to

No, I just have my own question.

I was wondering when
you learn dynamics

and you constrain them
to be controllable,

do you have any insights
on what would happen

if the dynamics that
you're trying to learn

are not actually
controllable or maybe there

is some subset of the
states that are controllable
and some that are uncontrolled?

Are there ways to extend your
methods to those settings

or what do you think would
happen when you try that?
I think you would have to--

you have to find some way of
dividing those things out.
I mean in linear systems--

I'm just spitballing
ideas now at this point.

The linear systems, you
can look at those ideas

like common decomposition
where you can break down

the controllable states from
the uncontrollable states

so you could look at imposing
that kind of structure.

I think much like in
model order reduction,

you'd have to maybe specify how
many states are uncontrollable

like a match, like picking the

Nonlinear analogs, I'm
not sure about but that's

the approach I would go
with something like that.
